title: Nike's Colin Kaepernick Campaign
summary: Nike's 'Dream Crazy' campaign featuring Colin Kaepernick was a high-stakes brand stand on racial justice that generated massive controversy, earned media, and ultimately record sales.
background: In 2018, Nike chose to feature Colin Kaepernick — the NFL quarterback who had been effectively blacklisted for kneeling during the national anthem — as the face of its 30th anniversary Just Do It campaign.
response: Nike's PR strategy combined a bold advertising launch with earned media management, social listening, and spokesperson coordination — accepting that significant backlash was inevitable and factoring it into the strategy.
outcome: While some consumers publicly burned Nike products, online sales increased 31% immediately after the campaign launched. Nike's brand value grew by $6 billion in the following months.
lessons: Brand values must be demonstrated, not just declared
Some audiences will reject bold stands — accept this
Controversy, managed well, generates disproportionate earned media
Consistency between brand values and actions builds long-term equity
discussion_questions: Was Nike's risk calculated or reckless?
What does this campaign say about the role of PR in brand management?
